Award.AwardTitle: Multimessenger Astrophysics: Real-time Discovery at Scale
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide support for participants to attend "Deep Learning for Multi-Messenger Astrophysics (MMA): Real-Time Discovery at Scale", a three-day workshop that will be held October 17-19, 2018 at the National Center for Supercomputing Applications (NCSA) at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. The purpose of the workshop is to catalyze the creation of a community whose expertise is at the interface of two of NSF's 10 Big Ideas: Harnessing the Data Revolution and Windows on the Universe. Domain experts attending this event will inform the design of a roadmap of future collaborations to accelerate convergence between these two disparate frontiers of science and technology to fully realize MMA.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The production of data sets, by physics and astronomy facilities, that vary in volume, speed, complexity and completeness have led to a common set of cyberinfrastructure needs, namely, the fusion of disparate data sets in real-time and at scale to maximize scientific discovery using multiple cosmic messengers (gravitational waves, electromagnetic waves, neutrinos and cosmic rays); and the development of novel signal-processing tools and computing paradigms to enable these analyses using oversubscribed computational resources. To respond to these timely and relevant challenges, this award was utilized to gather insights from disparate communities conducting research in Multi-Messenger Astrophysics, Artificial Intelligence, High Performance Computing, Software and Data. This project serves the national interest, as stated by NSF's mission, by promoting the progress of science under the umbrella of NSF’s Ten Big Ideas, namely, Growing Convergence Research, Harnessing the Data Revolution and Windows on the Universe.

 

Trough expert panel discussions, lightning talks and hands-on sessions, knowledge and insights were gathered from these communities to identify key developments in the computer science community that may be relevant to address grand computational challenges in Multi-Messenger Astrophysics. Highlights from these discussions and findings were published in EA Huerta et al., Nature Reviews Physics volume 1, pages 600–608 (2019).

 

This event also enabled interactions with NVIDIA and IBM, which provided a high-level description on the landscape of AI, both at the software and hardware level, over the next few years. These interactions highlighted the need to establish closer collaborations between academia and industry to harness the rapidly-changing field of innovation in AI to drive beneficial societal and economic benefits.
